Shape: Mississippi Kites are slender, fairly small raptors with long, pointed wings. The tail is fairly long and square-tipped. The strongly hooked bill is small and delicate.
Compared Size: Larger than a Rock Pigeon; smaller than a Peregrine Falcon.

description: Mississippi Kites are an inky mix of gray and black, lightening to pale gray-white on the head and in the secondaries of the wings. The wingtips and tail are black. Juveniles are streaky, with brownish chests and underwings, and banded tails.

These birds are excellent aerialists, spending much of their time aloft and sailing in the wind or flying with buoyant wingbeats. They are agile enough to catch insects, even dragonflies, on the wing. They may form large flocks during migration.
They live in bottomland hardwood forests of the Southeast and in tree-lined areas of the southern prairies including windbreaks, shelterbelts, parks, and urban areas.
